results.title: My mother was never a kid
results.creator_credit: Robert Fuest, Doro Bachrach, Franklin Getchell and Highgate Pictures
results.brief_description: Victoria Martin is a thirteen-year-old, who is confused by teenagehood and adults. After a fall she finds herself back in 1944 when her mother was young. When she returns to modern times she realises that grown-ups were once teenagers and had their problems too. Based on Francine Pascal’s “Hangin’ out with Cici”. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: My mother India
results.creator_credit: Safina Uberoi, Penny McDonald, Chili Films and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: My mother India begins by telling a love story. A young middle-class Australian woman falls in love with a young intellectual Indian whilst at university during the 1950s. They eventually marry and the Australian woman leaves her country to begin a new life in India as a wife and mother. This is an extraordinary documentary about living in a different culture and the way a nation’s political and historical turmoil impacts upon the lives of ordinary individuals. It weaves together first-person interviews, historic footage and present-day shots of India in a very beautiful and poetic way. The poignant and heartfelt quality of this documentary derives from the fact that the filmmaker, Safina Uberoi, is the daughter of this mixed racial couple, and the film is her personal quest for identity. Throughout she becomes reacquainted with her parents and her Indian grandparents and comes to fully understand and appreciate the kinds of sacrifices they made and suffering they endured. Ultimately, however, “My mother India” is a daughter paying homage to her mother and the tough decision she made a generation ago that now allows her daughter to move freely between two radically different countries and cultures. Winner of several awards including Best Australian Documentary, Real Life on Film Documentary Festival; Jury Prize for Best Australian Documentary, Australian Film Critics Circle; Special Jury Award, Hawaii International Film Festival; Best Long-Form Documentary, Australian Teachers of Media Awards.

results.title: My man Godfrey
results.creator_credit: Gregory La Cava and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: This is one of the classic screwball comedies of its time. An heiress (Carole Lombard), hires a butler (William Powell) after finding him on a scavenger hunt. She and her family are under the impression that he is a tramp without a job. He decides to teach “High Society” that money isn’t everything, and in the tradition of screwball comedy gets his girl as well as making his point. The film was unsuccessful at the Academy Awards despite six nominations but remains one of the best of its genre. Based on the novel by Eric Hatch.

results.title: Noel Coward: private lives
results.creator_credit: John Gorrie, Laurence Rees, Cedric Messina and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Tape 1 - Private Lives. On the first night of her honeymoon Amanda (Penelope Keith) feels that everything is perfect. The hotel room has a spectacular view, the cocktails are on the way and close by someone is singing a love song. To her horror she discovers that ‘someone’ is actually her ex-husband, also on honeymoon in a neighbouring hotel room. Noel Coward’s script is as relevant today as when it was first written in 1930 when he also played the lead role. The dialogue is quickly paced and full of wit and insightful observations. Tape 2 - Noel Coward: A Private Life. This is a biographical documentary about the life and early success of Noel Coward as a child actor and then as a playwright and performer in the 1920s and ‘30s through to the post war years. The documentary contains footage from his performances as well as interviews with those who knew him providing a revealing insight into Coward’s discrete private life that was significantly separate from his public image.

results.title: Nobody will speak of us when we are dead = Nadie hablara de nosotras cuando hayamos muerto [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Agustin Diaz Yanes, Edmundo Gil Casas, Flamenco Films SA, Renin and Xaloc SA
results.brief_description:
Gloria turns to prostitution to support her alcohol addiction after her bullfighter husband is seriously injured. We first see Gloria on the job for a group of Mexican money launderers. Things go awry when one of the clients, an undercover DEA agent is murdered. Gloria is the only witness, and after a pique of generosity, is handed a list of contacts in Spain. Eventually deported, Gloria returns to Madrid, contacts in hand, to the home of her mother-in-law and invalid husband determined to start a new life but is pursued by one of the hitmen. An interesting subplot involves his daughter’s illness exacerbated by her father’s profession, seemingly as an act of God. Hailed as a Spanish “Pulp fiction”, “Nobody will speak of us when we’re dead” received the 1995 Goya Award for Best Picture. In Spanish with English subtitles.
Cast includes: Victoria Abril, Pilar Bardem, Federico Luppi

results.title: Noah's ark
results.creator_credit: John irvin, Stephen Jones and Babelsberg International Film Produktion
results.brief_description: Australia provides the backdrop for this loose retelling of the eternal story of biblical hero Noah (Jon Voight), the great flood that destroyed the world, and the ark that was built by Noah and his family and housed two of every animal species. This made for television movie was not well received by critics, despite its international cast of Jon Voight, Mary Steenburgen and F. Murray Abraham.

results.title: Kama sutra: a tale of love
results.creator_credit: Mira Nair, Lydia Dean Pilcher, Mirabai Films, NDF International, Pandora Films and Pony Canyon
results.brief_description: Centred on the text The Kama Sutra this is a film about class and politics in sixteenth century India - a lush melodrama, featuring explicit sexual posturing. Initially it is the story of two women: Maya, a rebellious servant girl and Tara her mistress and future queen, childhood friends who become adult rivals. Publicly humiliated during Tara’s nuptial celebrations, a vengeful Maya seduces the king prior to his wedding night. Consequently Maya is spurned and turned out into the street, despite the king’s burgeoning obsession for her. Maya has an affair with a sculptor of erotic deities, before training as a courtesan, returning to the palace as a professional seductress. Meanwhile the king has fallen into an opium addled, hedonistic stupor that threatens the future of the kingdom. Mira Nair’s (Mississippi Masala, Salaam Bombay!, Monsoon Wedding) film operates as a critique of the class system and is a tract about self-determination and sexual politics, but it is overwhelmed by a simplistic script and predictable character developments. Nair may have been reaching for a feminist interpretation of the classic erotic text, as well as a narrative about spiritual awakening, but the key joys here are the rich colourful palette and exotic setting.
